facts.text: Three petitions made in the Bombay High Court for writs of mandamus under article 266 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: They arise out of three petitions made in the Bombay High Court for writs of mandamus under article 266 of the Constitution. The writs have been granted and the State of Bombay appeals.

facts.text: Writs of mandamus granted by Bombay High Court

anchor.surface_text: The writs have been granted and the State of Bombay appeals. The facts are these.

facts.text: State of Bombay appeals against grant of writs

anchor.surface_text: The writs have been granted and the State of Bombay appeals. The facts are these.

facts.text: Governor of Bombay acting through Assistant Controller of Accommodation issued requisition orders under section 6(4)(a) of Bombay Land Requisition Act 1948 for Civil Appeals Nos 145 and 146 of 1952

anchor.surface_text: The Governor of Bombay, acting through the Assistant Controller of Accommodation, issued orders under section 6 4  a  of the Bombay Land Requisition Act, 1948, in Civil Appeals Nos. 145 and 146 of 1952

facts.text: Governor of Bombay issued requisition order under section 5(1) for Civil Appeal No 147 of 1952

anchor.surface_text: and under section 5 1  in Civil Appeal No. 147 of 1952, requisitioning the premises of the three respondents. The question is whether these orders are ultra vires.

facts.text: Premises requisitioned belonging to three respondents

anchor.surface_text: requisitioning the premises of the three respondents. The question is whether these orders are ultra vires.

facts.text: In Civil Appeal No 145 of 1952 respondents are uncle and nephew first respondent uncle is tenant second respondent nephew lives with family in premises

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeal No. 145 of 1952 the respondents are uncle and nephew. The uncle, who is the first respondent, is the tenant. The second respondent in his nephew.

facts.text: In Civil Appeal No 146 of 1952 premises owned by trust first and second respondents trustees third respondent claims licensee

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeal No. 146 of 1952 the premises are owned by a trust. The first and second respondents are the trustees and the third respondents claims to be a licensee living on the premises.

facts.text: State of Bombay contends third respondent in CA 146 is tenant

anchor.surface_text: The State of Bombay companytends that he is a tenant but that is numberlonger of companysequence because of the assurance given by the learned Attorney-General

facts.text: In Civil Appeal No 147 of 1952 one respondent private limited company occupies premises as tenant for business

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeal No. 147 of 1952 there is only one respondent, a private limited companypany which occupies the requisitioned premises as a tenant for the purposes of its business.

facts.text: Bombay Land Requisition Act 1948 would have expired in April 1950

anchor.surface_text: The Act of 1948 would have expired in April, 1950, but its life was extended by Bombay Act II of 1950.

facts.text: Life of Bombay Land Requisition Act 1948 extended by Bombay Act II of 1950

anchor.surface_text: but its life was extended by Bombay Act II of 1950. Later, sections 5 and 6 were amended by Bombay Act XXXIX of 1950.

facts.text: Sections 5 and 6 of Act amended by Bombay Act XXXIX of 1950

anchor.surface_text: Later, sections 5 and 6 were amended by Bombay Act XXXIX of 1950.

facts.text: Petitions filed on 30th April 1951 and 4th April 1951

anchor.surface_text: The petitions in these two cases were filed on the 30th and 4th of April, 1951, respectively.

facts.text: Affidavits in reply filed on 18th and 19th June 1951

anchor.surface_text: Affidavits in reply were made on the 18th and 19th of June, and then in August, 1951,

facts.text: Order served in August 1951 declaring premises requisitioned for public purpose housing person without housing accommodation

anchor.surface_text: In companytinuation of the order dated etc the Government of Bombay is pleased to declare that the premises mentioned in that order were requisitioned for a public purpose, namely housing a person having numberhousing accommodation

facts.text: Housing situation in Bombay acute due to influx of refugees

anchor.surface_text: At that time the housing situation in Bombay was acute, largely due to the influx of refugees.

facts.text: In 1947 Government of Bombay passed Bombay Land Requisition Ordinance invited applications for allotment of vacancies

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1947 the Government of Bombay passed the Bombay Land Requisition Ordinance and invited applications for the allotment of vacancies from the general public.

facts.text: Landlords and tenants required to give notice of vacancies but many cases not done

anchor.surface_text: But the proper working of this scheme depended on the companyoperation of the landlords and tenants who were required by the law to give numberice of vacancies in occupation as they arose. It was found that in a very large number of cases this was number done

facts.text: Government allotted suppressed vacancies to first informants who needed accommodation

anchor.surface_text: Government accordingly introduced another class of beneficiaries, namely, those who gave information about what it called suppressed vacancies and numberinal occupation. It was decided to allot premises thus discovered to be vacant to the first informant

facts.text: In 1949 and 1950 Government restricted allotments to Government and public purposes

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, in 1949, and again in 1950, Government declared that it would number companysider further applications from the public as it had decided to restrict the allotments to Government and other public purposes.

facts.text: Allottees in present appeals are first informants

anchor.surface_text: The allottees in the present appeals are from that class.

facts.text: Learned Attorney-General gave assurance that possession of petitioners will not be disturbed

anchor.surface_text: but that is numberlonger of companysequence because of the assurance given by the learned Attorney-General that the possession of the petitioners in this case will number be disturbed for any reason arising out of these proceedings.

facts.text: In CA 146 premises question whether within section 4(3) let or intended to be let

anchor.surface_text: Under the Act only premises  to which a special meaning is given  within the meaning of section 4 3  can be requisitioned. It was urged that the premises in this case were number premises within the meaning of that definition

facts.text: Learned trial judge placed burden of proof on State Government

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial Judge threw the burden of proof on the State Government and told its learned companynsel that he should proceed to prove this fact if he so desired.

facts.text: State counsel did not lead evidence on premises definition in CA 146

anchor.surface_text: He replied that he did number intend to lead any evidence. It was explained to us that Government took up this attitude as it wanted a decision about where the burden lay

facts.text: Civil Appeal No 146 dismissed due to Attorney-General assurance no order as to costs

anchor.surface_text: This appeal will accordingly be dismissed because of the assurance given and there will be numberorder about companyts throughout.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos 145 and 147 allowed petitions dismissed no costs

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 145 and 147 of 1952 are allowed and the petitions in these two cases will be dismissed but here also there will be numberorder about companyts throughout.
They arise out of three petitions made in the Bombay High Court for writs of mandamus under article 266 of the Constitution. The writs have been granted and the State of Bombay appeals.

issues.text: The question is whether these orders are ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: requisitioning the premises of the three respondents. The question is whether these orders are ultra vires. They are attacked on a number of grounds the first of which goes to the root of the matter.

anchor.surface_text: They are attacked on a number of grounds the first of which goes to the root of the matter. It is contended that these two sections are ultra vires articles 19 1 f and 31 2 of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether article 19(1)(f) applies to tenants and licensees

anchor.surface_text: We will first deal with Civil Appeals Nos. 145 and 146 of 1952 where tenants and licensees are concerned. In our opinion, article 19 1 f does not apply to them. In The State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose

issues.text: whether the requisition was for a public purpose

anchor.surface_text: The Act provides for compensation in section 8, so all we have to see is whether the requisition was for a public purpose. The main Act is pre-Constitution and at that time there were no fundamental rights

issues.text: The first question, therefore, is, whether they were made for a State or public purpose as set out in sections 5(1) and 6(4)

anchor.surface_text: Following that decision we hold that the Act is not invalid for this reason. We now turn to the orders of requisition. They can only be upheld if they conform to the provisions of the Act. The first question, therefore, is, whether they were made for a State or public purpose

arguments.claim: sections 5 and 6 of Bombay Land Requisition Act are ultra vires articles 19(1)(f) and 31(2) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether these orders are ultra vires. They are attacked on a number of grounds the first of which goes to the root of the matter. It is contended that these two sections are ultra vires articles 19 1 f and 31 2 of the Constitution. The respondents are either the owners or the tenants of the premises requisitioned.

arguments.court_reasoning: Article 19(1)(f) does not apply due to substantial deprivation invoking Article 31; compensation under s8; public purpose inferable from Act

arguments.claim: restrictions imposed by the Act on right to hold, acquire and dispose of property are neither reasonable nor in interests of general public

anchor.surface_text: As the later Acts were after the Constitution and as the life of the main Act was extended after the Constitution came into force, it is said that they are all hit by article 19 1 f and 31 2 , firstly, because the restrictions imposed on the right to hold, acquire and dispose of property are neither reasonable nor in the interests of the general public

arguments.court_reasoning: Article 19(1)(f) presupposes property that can be enjoyed; substantial deprivation excludes it per precedents

arguments.claim: Article 19(1)(f) does not apply to tenants and licensees due to substantial deprivation of property rights

anchor.surface_text: We will first deal with Civil Appeals Nos. 145 and 146 of 1952 where tenants and licensees are concerned. In our opinion, article 19 1 f does not apply to them. In The State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose 1954 S.C.R. 587 , and Dwarkadas Shrinivas of Bombay v. The Sholapur Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd. Others 1954 S.C.R. 674 ,

arguments.claim: Articles 19(1)(f) and 31 cover different fields with no overlapping

anchor.surface_text: the majority of the Judges were agreed that articles 19 1 f and 31 deal with different subjects and cover different fields. There was some disagreement about the nature and scope of the difference but all were agreed that there was no overlapping.

arguments.claim: Article 19(1)(f) postulates existence of property which can be enjoyed; substantial deprivation invokes Article 31

anchor.surface_text: We need not examine those differences here because it is enough to say that article 19 1 f read with clause 5 postulates the existence of property which can be enjoyed and over which rights can be exercised... when there is a substantially total deprivation of property which is already held and enjoyed, one must turn to article 31

arguments.claim: Article 19(1)(f) deals with substantial rights not illusory title; requisition takes away all enjoyment leaving husk

anchor.surface_text: These articles deal with substantial and substantive rights and not with illusory phantoms of title. When every form of enjoyment which normally accompanies an interest in this kind of property is taken away leaving the mere husk of title, article 19 is not attracted.
The Act provides for compensation in section 8, so all we have to see is whether the requisition was for a public purpose.

arguments.claim: Act valid as public purpose inferable from tenor, preamble, ss5 and 6

anchor.surface_text: The main Act is pre-Constitution... sections 5 and 6 as now amended contain the words for the purpose of the State or any other public purpose. Our present Chief Justice... pointed out... It is unnecessary to state in express terms in the statute itself the precise purpose... Following that decision we hold that the Act is not invalid for this reason.

arguments.claim: subsequent specification of public purpose in order is of no avail and is afterthought not true

anchor.surface_text: It was argued that this subsequent specification of the purpose is of no avail and that in any case it is an evident afterthought and not true.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: appeals are from that class. Despite this it was found that the number of applications so far exceeded the number of vacancies that there was number e

arguments.court_reasoning: Not necessary to set out purpose in order itself; omission not fatal if proven otherwise; principle from Biswabhusan Naik

arguments.claim: not necessary to set out purpose of requisition in the order

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, it is not necessary to set out the purpose of the requisition in the order. The desirability of such a course is obvious... But in itself an omission to set out the purpose in the order is not fatal so long as the facts are established... The underlying principle of our decision in Biswabhusan Naik v. The State of Orissa applies here.

arguments.claim: there is proof of public purpose: housing homeless amid crisis

anchor.surface_text: In the present set of cases there is proof of a public purpose. It is given in the affidavits... namely to house the homeless. At that time the housing situation in Bombay was acute... It was necessary therefore for government take more drastic steps and in doing so they acted for the public weal.

arguments.claim: allotting suppressed vacancies to first informants who need accommodation is not public purpose but reward to informers for privileged govt servants

arguments.court_reasoning: Purpose is housing homeless; fulfilled if allottee houseless; wide govt discretion in choosing amid scarcity; no fraud alleged

arguments.claim: policy of allotting to first informants fulfills public purpose of housing homeless; govt has discretion balancing factors

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this is not a proper approach to the problem. The Constitution authorises requisitions for a public purpose. The purpose here is finding accommodation for the homeless. If therefore a vacancy is allotted to a person who is in fact houseless, the purpose is fulfilled... Government had to weigh many conflicting factors...

arguments.claim: equitable distribution not achieved by rewarding informers/spies regardless of need

court_response_anchor.surface_text: stribution of vacant accommodation this fell outside its scope. In our opinion, this is number a proper approach to the problem. The Constitution auth

arguments.court_reasoning: Not proper approach; purpose fulfilled if homeless housed; discretion includes equity helps vigilant

arguments.claim: burden of proof on petitioners to show order illegal

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the burden was wrongly placed. The petitioners came to Court with the allegation that Government had passed an illegal order against them. On the face of it, the order is not illegal... It was therefore the duty of the petitioners to show that the order was illegal.

holdings.text: article 19(1)(f) does not apply to tenants and licensees

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, article 19 1 f does number apply to them. In The State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose  1954 S.C.R. 587 , and Dwarkadas Shrinivas of Bombay v. The Sholapur Spinning and Weaving Co. Ltd. Others  1954 S.C.R. 674 , the majority of the Judges were agreed that articles 19 1 f and 31 deal with different subjects and companyer different fields.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substantial deprivation of property rights invokes Article 31, not 19(1)(f); follows precedents like Subodh Gopal Bose and Dwarkadas Shrinivas

holdings.text: articles 19(1)(f) and 31 deal with different subjects and cover different fields with no overlapping

anchor.surface_text: the majority of the Judges were agreed that articles 19 1 f and 31 deal with different subjects and companyer different fields. There was some disagreement about the nature and scope of the difference but all were agreed that there was numberoverlapping.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents establish distinction; Article 19(1)(f) presupposes enjoyable property

holdings.text: article 19(1)(f) postulates existence of property which can be enjoyed

anchor.surface_text: We need number examine those differences here because it is enough to say that article 19 1 f read with clause  5  postulates the existence of property which can be enjoyed and over which rights can be exercised because otherwise the reasonable restrictions companytemplated by clause  5  companyld number be brought into play.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation; reasonable restrictions under clause 5 require exercisable rights; analogy to Gopalan on personal freedoms

holdings.text: Bombay Land Requisition Act not invalid for lack of public purpose requirement

anchor.surface_text: Following that decision we hold that the Act is number invalid for this reason. We number turn to the orders of requisition. They can only be upheld if they companyform to the provisions of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Public purpose inferable from preamble, sections 5 and 6, and tenor of Act per Kameshwar Singh precedent

anchor.surface_text: The Act provides for companypensation in section 8, so all we have to see is whether the requisition was for a public purpose.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of Act's compensation provision to constitutional requirement

holdings.text: not necessary to set out purpose of requisition in the order

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, it is number necessary to set out the purpose of the requisition in the order. The desirability of such a companyrse is obvious because when it is number done proof of the purpose must be given in other ways

holdings.reasoning_summary: Omission not fatal if purpose proven otherwise; principle from Biswabhusan Naik

holdings.text: requisition orders made for public purpose of housing homeless

anchor.surface_text: In the present set of cases there is proof of a public purpose. It is given in the affidavits made on behalf of the State and in the subsequent orders just quoted, namely to house the homeless. At that time the housing situation in Bombay was acute

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proof in affidavits and context of housing crisis; fulfills State/public purpose under ss 5(1), 6(4)

holdings.text: allotment to first informants fulfills public purpose given government discretion

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this is number a proper approach to the problem. The Constitution authorises requisitions for a public purpose. The purpose here is finding accommodation for the homeless. If therefore a vacancy is allotted to a person who is in fact houseless, the purpose is fulfilled

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purpose housing homeless met if allottee houseless; discretion to balance factors like equity, morale; no fraud alleged

holdings.text: neither order of requisition nor allotment in CA 145 and 146 ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: We hold that neither the order of requisition number the order of allotment in Civil Appeals Nos. 145 and 146 of 1952 is ultra vires.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Comply with Act and Constitution on public purpose and compensation

holdings.text: burden of proof wrongly placed on State; burden on petitioners

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the burden was wrongly placed. The petitioners came to Court with the allegation that Government had passed an illegal order against them. On the face of it, the order is number illegal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumptively valid order; petitioners allege illegality and have special knowledge

holdings.text: requisition order in CA 147 valid for same reasons

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons already given, we held that there was a public purpose and that the orders here were valid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies prior holdings on public purpose

precedents.cited_proposition: substantial deprivation means deprivation that robs of attributes of enjoyment normally accompanying property rights; substance over form
precedents.cited_holding: By substantial deprivation is meant the sort of deprivation that substantially robs a man of those attributes of enjoyment which numbermally accompany rights to, or an interest in, property. The form is unessential. It is the substance that one must seek.

precedents.cited_proposition: unnecessary to state precise purpose expressly in statute if gathered from whole tenor that for state or public purpose benefiting community
precedents.cited_holding: It is unnecessary to state in express terms in the statute itself the precise purpose for which property is being taken, provided from the whole tenor and intendment of the Act it companyld be gathered that the property was being acquired either for purposes of the State or for purposes of the public and that the intention was to benefit the companymunity at large.
